questions.question_text:
A company uses Exchange Online. External sharing is disabled.
A user reports that they are unable to share their calendar with an external recipient.
You need to resolve the issue.
Solution: Grant anonymous permission to the userâ€™s calendar.
Does the solution meet the goal?

A company uses Exchange Online. The company configures a transport rule that appends to emails from external senders.
Users report that they are unable to accept calendar invitations from external senders.
You need to ensure that users can accept calendar invitations.
What are two possible ways to achieve this goal? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

choices.A: Change the fallback action on the transport rule to reject.
choices.B: Configure an exception on the transport rule to skip calendar invites.
choices.D: Select the Stop processing more rules option on the transport rule.
choices.C: Change the fallback action on the transport rule to ignore.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
BC is the answer

Selected Answer: BC

Sorry, changed my mind to BC. Look here. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/troubleshoot/outlook-on-the-web-issues/cannot-open-calendar-from-sharing-invitation

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
A company uses Exchange Online. The company configures a room mailbox named Room1 to use resource delegates.
Resource delegates report that they are not able to approve meeting requests for Room1.
You need to ensure that resource delegates receive meeting request emails.
How should you complete the command? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
//IMG//

discussion.content:
I think it's Auto-Update
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/set-calendarprocessing?view=exchange-ps#-automateprocessing
AutoUpdate: Only the Calendar Attendant processes meeting requests and responses. Meeting requests are tentative in the calendar until they're approved by a delegate. Meeting organizers receive only decisions from delegates.
AutoAccept: Both the Calendar Attendant and resource booking attendant are enabled on the mailbox. This means that the Calendar Attendant updates the calendar, and then the resource booking assistant accepts the meeting based upon the policies. Eligible meeting organizers receive the decision directly without human intervention (free = accept; busy = decline).

I think AutoUpdate.
Lets review the question, the delegates are not able to approve the requests.
That states that they either have no access OR AutoAccept is already in place!
So we should change it to AutoUpdate

AutoUpdate: Only the Calendar Attendant processes meeting requests and responses. Meeting requests are tentative in the calendar until they're approved by a delegate. Meeting organizers receive only decisions from delegates.
AutoAccept: Both the Calendar Attendant and resource booking attendant are enabled on the mailbox. This means that the Calendar Attendant updates the calendar, and then the resource booking assistant accepts the meeting based upon the policies. Eligible meeting organizers receive the decision directly without human intervention (free = accept; busy = decline).

Correct~
Example: Set-CalendarProcessing -Identity "5th Floor Conference Room" -AutomateProcessing AutoAccept -AllRequestInPolicy $true -AllBookInPolicy $false -ResourceDelegates "chris@contoso.com","michelle@contoso.com"

-This example allows all users to submit in-policy requests, but the request is still subject to approval by one of the specified delegates.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
A company uses Exchange Online. The Exchange ActiveSync access setting is configured to quarantine.
A user named User1 removes a mobile device from Exchange.
When User1 tries to connect the same device to Exchange, the device is not quarantined.
You need to ensure that the device is quarantined.
How should you complete the command? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I think D is the correct answer

Selected Answer: D
Agree,

When a conference room mailbox is already reserved for another meeting and a conflicting meeting request is sent, Exchange Online will automatically decline the conflicting meeting request if the AllRequestOutOfPolicy property for the room mailbox is set to True. In this case, since the conflicting meeting request is not being declined, the AllRequestOutOfPolicy property must be set to False. By doing this, you will ensure that any conflicting meeting requests sent to Conf1 will be automatically declined, preventing double booking of the room.

Selected Answer: D
Agree with D

D is correct~

There is NO AllBlockinPolicy :)

choices.A: Set the value of the AllBlockInPolicy property for the room mailbox to False.
choices.D: Set the value of the AllRequestOutOfPolicy property for the room mailbox to False.
choices.B: Remove User1 from the BookInPolicy property list.
choices.C: Remove User1 from the ResourceDelegated property list.

questions.question_text:
A company uses Exchange Online.
A user named User1 schedules a meeting with a conference room mailbox named Conf1. Conf1 is already reserved for another meeting but does not automatically decline the conflicting meeting request.
You need to ensure that conflicting meeting requests sent to Conf1 are declined.
What should you do?
